awd_titl_txt: RR Standard: Reproducibility and the Scientific Crisis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will follow controversies of reproducibility in science by looking at research oversight institutions, journal piracy and open access responses. For each domain the project will assess how different actors understand and act upon these crises in science to create robust and reliable science. It will study how their actions and reforms are transforming scientific organization and practices. The broader aim is to offer tools and knowledge for policy makers, reformers, activists, publishers, and journalists seeking to promote reliable and robust science. The study will help identify suggestions for alleviating some of the hidden issues and conflicts within and among reform strategies. It will provide insights for understanding research and public intersections. The findings will be of interest to scientists, science communicators, educators, public, research organizations, scientific publishers and policymakers. 

This study will explore the construction of factors that place pressure on science in the production, management, and dissemination of biomedical and behavioral research. It will use interviews, document analysis, and participant observation to compare responses to pressure and reform efforts across domains of knowledge production (reproducibility), oversight (post publication peer review), and research dissemination (open publishing and piracy). By using STS theories that address the relation of social order to knowledge production, this project will explore changes in the organization of science, the relationship between scientific practice and extra-scientific environments, and the perceived inadequacy of prevailing models of science. Thus, in each domain the project's first aim is to understand how perceptions of pressure are related to institutional and practical change in science. Second, these changes are compared to STS theories of scientific order and change to speak to how effective the reforms are at restoring order and changing actors' perceptions.

por.por_cntn:
In the past two decades, debates about the validity of science have become commonplace in civil discourse. While grappling with attacks on the legitimacy of science from external political and cultural actors, scientists and policymakers have been dealing with their own crises of epistemic doubt. Scientists have raised public concerns, for example, about the replication crisis, the rising rate of retraction, recent high-profile cases of scientific fraud, concerns that pharmaceutical innovation is failing, and that false research outweighs proven research in journals. How have scientists responded to these perceptions of crisis? Drawing from Science and Technology Studies (STS) theories and using qualitative, interpretive research methods, we conducted over 150 interviews with prominent scientists, science activists, funders, journal editors, organization leaders, and policy makers, and reviewed hundreds of published scientific articles, white papers, journalistic pieces, and websites. Our core discovery and the focus of our research was the emergence of a social movement within science that seeks to turn the tools of science?measurement, quantification, and experimentation?on the practices of science. This emergent metascience is a transdisciplinary field that straddles the border between academic research and policymaking. Using evidence from empirical studies of science, these activists have pushed to increase transparency in research practice, incentivize auditing practices, and reduce frictions in data storage, exchange, and reuse.

Two major findings stem from our research. First, discussions about science reform would benefit from greater input from STS scholars. Though engaging in research that uses a variety of cutting-edge methods including Big Data studies of science and mass replications, much of the discussion around science reform has belied simplified sociological assumptions and outdated philosophies of science. For instance, adopting a falsification framework, metascientists have placed explicit, public, and exact replications at the center of science?s formal self-correction mechanism.  Our research shows that while such explicitly ?diagnostic? replications are important for self-correction in some fields, sciences that have rapidly evolving technologies engage in large amounts of ?integrative? replication which is a significant informal self-correction method. Greater dialogue with STS research on the diversity of scientific practice would ensure that science reforms are targeted and sensitive to different epistemic contexts.

Our second major finding is that the metascience movement is laying the groundwork for a radically different future of science. Policies that incentivize or mandate research transparency and open data have been promoted on the basis of helping to legitimate science. Yet, these same policies are accelerating datafication across science. Although fields like genomics have already undergone this transition, widespread open data policies will lead to greater data-centrism in all empirical fields. These changes will have far reaching consequences for relationships among scientists, between disciplines, and research organizations, and will be one of the most significant topics in science studies in the coming decades.
